column1: Honorary Professor, Zhejiang Academy of Agricultural Sciences, Hangzhou, People's Republic of China

Notice: Although I am no longer employed by Rothamsted Research, I still have an office and e-mail account and will be continuing my collaboration with Zhejiang Academy of Agricultural Sciences. This will include maintaining an interest in plant virus taxonomy and sequence analysis.

For some years I tested barley samples for mosaic virus as part of a long-running survey. I regret that we can no longer receive samples on this basis. However, Dr Kostya Kanyuka is still keen to obtain resistant barley or any wheat samples that may be infected with soil-borne viruses.

• Studies of the fungally transmitted viruses of cereals (especially the bymo- and furo-viruses in Europe and China) and their vector, Polymyxa graminis.

    The main aims were to investigate the mechanism of virus transmission, the epidemiology and control of the diseases, the variability in the virus genomes and the biology and ecology of the vector (traditionally regarded as a fungus but now often classified as a protist). This work was funded by BBSRC, DEFRA, H-GCA and the EU. The members of the team were:
• Dr Kostya Kanyuka: molecular virology and genetics of host plant resistance
• Dr Chris Bass: (50% with Kostya until September 2006)
• Khalid Alhudaib: PhD student working on the P2 protein of Barley mild mosaic virus
column2: jointly supervised by Mike and Kostya (until July 2006)

column1: • Rebecca Lyons: PhD student working on genetics of resistance to furoviruses in wheat
column2: jointly supervised by Kim Hammond-Kosack and Kostya

column1: • Dr Elaine Ward: molecular and diagnostic aspects of Polymyxa
• Madeleine Smith: PhD student working on characterisation of ribotypes of Polymyxa graminis
column2: jointly supervised by Mike and Elaine

column1:
• Comparative genome analysis of plant viruses.

    In collaboration with Dr John Antoniw, and arising from our work on the AAB Descriptions of Plant Viruses, a comprehensive sequence database for plant (and some other) viruses has been created and software is being developed to exploit this resource. Full details of the CD-ROM marketed by AAB and the related web resources can be found on the DPV Web pages. I also act as advisor on plant viruses to the NCBI RefSeq project and am the Plant virus Subcommittee Chair for the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV). This work is continuing despite my retirement.

• Characterisation of plant viruses in China.

    This work is part of a very productive collaboration with Prof Dr Chen Jianping and colleagues at the Zhejang Academy of Agricultural Sciences, Hangzhou, People's Republic of China. Molecular and biological characterisation and phylogenetic analyses are identifying viruses of many crops in China, particularly those from the genera Potyvirus and Carlavirus. A full list of our joint publications can be found here.
Some pictures related to the barley mosaic viruses

The barley mosaic viruses are usually first noticed in the winter or early spring as yellow patches in the crop. This field had a mixture of both Barley yellow mosaic virus (BaYMV) and Barley mild mosaic virus (BaMMV).
The typical mosaic symptoms on the younger leaves are shown in this picture.
Barley mosaic viruses can be effectively controlled using resistant varieties as this photograph from a BaYMV trial in Gloucestershire, UK, shows dramatically.
Composite aerial photograph of the same trial taken by Dr Vick Jordan using a model aeroplane.

By flowering, symptoms of the mosaic viruses are usually difficult to find but crops can remain stunted as this picture illustrates. Severe infection by the mosaic viruses can result in yield losses of 30% or more.
Light micrograph of a typical, irregularly lobed, zoosporangium of Polymyxa graminis in a barley root cell (stained with trypan blue).
Light- and electron- micrographs showing the resting spore clusters ("cystosori") of Polymyxa graminis.

This site contains a virtually complete on-line version of the DPV program and much more. In addition to the individual virus descriptions, there is extensive taxonomic coverage (all viruses except those with a double-stranded DNA genome), classified lists of plant virus sequences and a new sequence database and software for rapid access to viral gene sequences and subsequent analyses. Details of the stand-alone CD-ROM version marketed by AAB can also be found on this site.
